title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with making globalization a reality in our lives?

options.label: A
options.text: Malcolm McLean

options.label: B
options.text: A renowned scientist

options.label: C
options.text: A famous inventor

options.label: D
options.text: A well-known entrepreneur

multiple-choice.question: What was the occupation of Malcolm McLean when he got the job to take cotton bales from Fayetteville in North Carolina to a pier in Hoboken, New Jersey?

options.label: A
options.text: Truck driver

options.label: B
options.text: Ship captain

options.label: C
options.text: Warehouse worker

options.label: D
options.text: Merchant

multiple-choice.question: What was the process called that Malcolm McLean observed at the docks, where crates and bundles were lifted and placed in the hold of the ship?

options.label: A
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: B
options.text: Containerization

options.label: C
options.text: Shipping by air

options.label: D
options.text: Rail transport

multiple-choice.question: What inspired Malcolm McLean to come up with the idea of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: His love for ships

options.label: B
options.text: Frustration with the slow process of break bulk shipping

options.label: C
options.text: Desire to make a lot of money

options.label: D
options.text: Need for a new job

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization affect the global marketplace?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced the variety of goods available

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the cost of shipping goods

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the movement of cargo from remote parts of the world at minimal cost

options.label: D
options.text: It slowed down the process of shipping goods

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship?

options.label: A
options.text: Ideal X

options.label: B
options.text: Container Queen

options.label: C
options.text: Shipping King

options.label: D
options.text: Break Bulk Express

multiple-choice.question: How many well-filled boxes did the Ideal X carry on its maiden voyage?
What was the estimated time saved by containerization in the process of hauling and distributing break bulk shipments?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 week

options.label: B
options.text: 2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 8 days

options.label: D
options.text: 16 days

multiple-choice.question: Who provided Malcolm McLean with the loan to design the steel boxes and the decks of the ships to carry the containers?

options.label: A
options.text: A bank in North Carolina

options.label: B
options.text: A vice president at Citibank in New York

options.label: C
options.text: A merchant in Hoboken

options.label: D
options.text: A ship captain in the US Navy

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decline in global trade

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in a reduction in the variety of goods available

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the movement of cargo from remote parts of the world at minimal cost

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on global trade

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary goal in the scene?

options.label: A
options.text: To receive financial aid for their education

options.label: B
options.text: To critique the education system and advocate for change

options.label: C
options.text: To entertain the audience with a rap performance

options.label: D
options.text: To perform a stand-up comedy routine

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the purpose of the financial aid system?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a fair opportunity for all students to achieve their educational goals

options.label: B
options.text: To keep students in debt and prevent them from achieving success

options.label: C
options.text: To punish students for their ancestors' past mistakes

options.label: D
options.text: To create a cycle of debt and limit students' access to resources

multiple-choice.question: What historical figure is mentioned in the transcript as having taught a system to keep people in debt and prevent them from achieving success?

options.label: A
options.text: Frederick Douglass, a prominent abolitionist

options.label: B
options.text: Martin Luther King Jr., a civil rights leader

options.label: C
options.text: Professor Willie Lynch, a figure associated with the exploitation of African Americans

options.label: D
options.text: Nelson Mandela, an anti-apartheid revolutionary

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's emotional state throughout the scene?

options.label: A
options.text: Calm and collected, with a hint of sarcasm

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and frustrated, with a sense of urgency

options.label: C
options.text: Happy and excited, with a touch of irony

options.label: D
options.text: Sad and disappointed, with a sense of hopelessness

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument against the financial aid system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is not enough to cover the cost of tuition, leading to students being in debt and limiting their access to resources

options.label: B
options.text: That it is too much and prevents students from achieving success

options.label: C
options.text: That it is unfair and only helps certain students

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a game and not a serious system

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for their education?

options.label: A
options.text: To achieve success and wealth, but at a cost

options.label: B
options.text: To learn and grow as a person, without being burdened by debt

options.label: C
options.text: To critique the education system and advocate for change

options.label: D
options.text: To entertain the audience with a performance

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's attitude towards the financial aid system?

options.label: A
options.text: They are neutral and indifferent, with a sense of resignation

options.label: B
options.text: They are angry and frustrated, with a sense of outrage

options.label: C
options.text: They are hopeful and optimistic, with a sense of optimism

options.label: D
options.text: They are disappointed and sad, with a sense of hopelessness

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To take out loans and go to college, but be aware of the consequences

options.label: B
options.text: To fight against the financial aid system and advocate for change

options.label: C
options.text: To be grateful for the opportunity to receive financial aid, but also be aware of its limitations

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the financial aid system and focus on their own goals

options.label: A
options.text: They are saying that it is unfair to keep people in debt

options.label: B
options.text: They are saying that it is a historical fact that people were kept in debt

options.label: C
options.text: They are saying that it is a reversal of the amendment, where people are kept in debt instead of being freed

options.label: D
options.text: They are saying that it is a myth

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's emotional appeal to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: They are asking for sympathy and understanding, but also for action

options.label: B
options.text: They are asking for help and support, but also for a change in the system

options.label: C
options.text: They are asking for forgiveness and a second chance, but also for a chance to make things right

options.label: D
options.text: They are asking the audience to take action and fight against the financial aid system, and to join them in their struggle for change

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for their cousins in Haiti and their best friend Raymond?

options.label: A
options.text: To help them achieve success and wealth

options.label: B
options.text: To help them learn and grow as people, without being burdened by debt

options.label: C
options.text: To help them fight against the financial aid system and advocate for change

options.label: D
options.text: To help them ignore the financial aid system and focus on their own goals

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's reference to the nooses hanging their GPA by its neck?

options.label: A
options.text: They are saying that their GPA is being unfairly punished

options.label: B
options.text: They are saying that their GPA is being unfairly rewarded

options.label: C
options.text: They are saying that their GPA is being unfairly used as a tool for oppression

options.label: D
options.text: They are saying that their GPA is being unfairly used as a tool for liberation

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone throughout the scene?

options.label: A
options.text: Sarcastic and ironic

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and frustrated

options.label: C
options.text: Hopeful and optimistic

options.label: D
options.text: Disappointed and sad

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the education system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is fair and provides equal opportunities for all students

options.label: B
options.text: That it is unfair and creates a cycle of debt and limited access to resources

options.label: C
options.text: That it is not relevant to the speaker's argument

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action?

options.label: A
options.text: To take out loans and go to college

options.label: B
options.text: To fight against the financial aid system and advocate for change

options.label: C
options.text: To be grateful for the opportunity to receive financial aid

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the financial aid system and focus on their own goals

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that Dorothy repeats in the classic scene from "The Wizard of Oz"?

options.label: A
options.text: "No coordinates exist like one's domicile."

options.label: B
options.text: "There's no place like home."

options.label: C
options.text: "I want to go home."

options.label: D
options.text: "I'm not from around here."

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main problem with using expensive words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too short.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too long.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be misunderstood by the audience, rendering them ineffective.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not interesting.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to know your audience when writing?

options.label: A
options.text: So you can tailor your writing to their needs and expectations, including their attention span and level of understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: You can use more expensive words that are unfamiliar to them.

options.label: C
options.text: You can write at a higher reading level.

options.label: D
options.text: You can ignore their feedback.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the author's argument about using expensive words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That bigger words are always better.

options.label: B
options.text: That variety is the key to effective writing.

options.label: C
options.text: That brevity is more important than using expensive words, as it helps to connect with the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: That writing should always be at a fourth-grade reading level.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what happens to expensive words that are not understood by the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more effective.

options.label: B
options.text: They fail to convey the intended meaning and lose their impact.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no impact.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more interesting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to connect with their audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Use more expensive words.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a higher reading level.

options.label: C
options.text: Get to the point and use concise language that is easy to understand.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore their feedback.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to consider the audience's attention span when writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a lot of time to read.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not interested in what you have to say.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are competing against a whole world of distractions, making it essential to be concise and clear.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not educated enough.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the relationship between variety and brevity in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Variety is the key to brevity.

options.label: B
options.text: Brevity is the key to variety.

options.label: C
options.text: Variety and brevity are mutually exclusive.

options.label: D
options.text: Variety is more important than brevity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion about using expensive words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always effective.

options.label: B
options.text: They are never effective.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be effective, but only if they are understood by the audience and used in the right context.

options.label: D
options.text: They can be effective, but are often not used effectively.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for writers who want to use expensive words effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Buy a thesaurus.

options.label: B
options.text: Use a Scrabble board as a reminder to keep your writing concise and easy to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: Read more books.

options.label: D
options.text: Practice writing more.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is a symbiosis in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where one species consumes another

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species

options.label: C
options.text: A competition between two species for resources

options.label: D
options.text: A process where one species adapts to its environment

multiple-choice.question: Which two species are involved in a symbiotic relationship described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's nutcracker and whitebark pine

options.label: B
options.text: Bees and flowers, Clark's nutcracker and whitebark pine

options.label: C
options.text: Squirrels and grizzlies, Clark's nutcracker and whitebark pine

options.label: D
options.text: Black bears and whitebark pine, Clark's nutcracker and whitebark pine

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets to keep all the seeds it gathers

options.label: B
options.text: The whitebark pine gets to keep all its seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Both species benefit from the partnership

options.label: D
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker replants the trees, while the whitebark pine feeds the forest

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique adaptation of the Clark's nutcracker that allows it to gather seeds from the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: Its powerful beak

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to fly quickly

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to remember where it caches seeds

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: How do the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine benefit from each other in the symbiotic relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets seeds, while the whitebark pine gets nothing

options.label: B
options.text: The whitebark pine gets seeds, while the Clark's nutcracker gets nothing

options.label: C
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker replants the trees, while the whitebark pine feeds the forest

options.label: D
options.text: Both species benefit from the partnership

multiple-choice.question: What is a strategy used by the Clark's nutcracker to remember where it caches seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: It uses a map

options.label: B
options.text: It uses landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: It uses a system of underground tunnels

options.label: D
options.text: It uses a combination of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the Clark's nutcracker in the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a predator that hunts other animals

options.label: B
options.text: It is a prey that is hunted by other animals

options.label: C
options.text: It is a seed disperser that replants trees

options.label: D
options.text: It is a scavenger that feeds on dead animals

multiple-choice.question: How has the Clark's nutcracker adapted to its environment in the symbiotic relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: It has developed a long, tough beak for extracting seeds from cones

options.label: B
options.text: It has developed a short, weak beak for extracting seeds from cones

options.label: C
options.text: It has developed the ability to fly quickly

options.label: D
options.text: It has developed the ability to remember where it caches seeds

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rare example of a symbiotic relationship

options.label: B
options.text: It is a unique adaptation of the Clark's nutcracker

options.label: C
options.text: It is an important part of the ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: It is a competition between two species for resources

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: One species benefits at the expense of the other

options.label: B
options.text: Both species benefit from the partnership

options.label: C
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker replants the trees, while the whitebark pine feeds the forest

options.label: D
options.text: The symbiotic relationship is a rare example in nature

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What concept did Richard Feynman's dad explain to him when he asked why the ball went to the back of the wagon?

options.label: A
options.text: Gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Friction

options.label: C
options.text: Inertia

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**: According to Aristotle, what shape constantly creates a circular shadow, which led him to prove that the Earth is round?

options.label: A
options.text: A sphere

options.label: B
options.text: A circle

options.label: C
options.text: An ellipse

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If Eratosthenes knew that the sun was directly above the city of Swenet and that a stick stuck in the ground in Alexandria at the same time and the same day, at noon, cast a shadow that showed it was 7.2 degrees off-axis, how could he use this information to estimate the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: By calculating the distance between Swenet and Alexandria and multiplying it by 50

options.label: B
options.text: By measuring the angle of the shadow in Swenet and comparing it to the angle in Alexandria

options.label: C
options.text: By using the distance between the two cities and the angle of the shadow to calculate the circumference

options.label: D
options.text: By using the angle of the shadow and the time of day to calculate the distance between the two cities

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: How did Fizeau's experiment using a toothed wheel and a beam of light help him determine the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: By measuring the time it took for the light to travel between the two stations

options.label: B
options.text: By counting the number of notches on the wheel and calculating the speed of the wheel

options.label: C
options.text: By noticing that the pulse of light was occluded by the wheel as it spun faster

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing the speed of the wheel to the speed of light

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How did the discoveries of Eratosthenes and Fizeau contribute to our understanding of the Earth and the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing accurate measurements of the Earth's diameter and the speed of light

options.label: B
options.text: By introducing new methods for calculating the circumference of the Earth and the speed of light

options.label: C
options.text: By demonstrating the importance of independent corroboration in scientific research

options.label: D
options.text: By showing that science is an open field of study that requires curiosity and exploration

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of the fact that Fizeau's experiment using a toothed wheel and a beam of light was able to determine the speed of light to within two percent of its actual value?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that Fizeau's method was highly accurate

options.label: B
options.text: It demonstrates the importance of using simple equipment in scientific research

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the significance of independent corroboration in scientific research

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that the speed of light is a fundamental constant that can be measured with high accuracy

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: Who was the third librarian at the great Library of Alexandria?

options.label: A
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: B
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: C
options.text: Galileo

options.label: D
options.text: Fizeau

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the main contribution of Eratosthenes to science?

options.label: A
options.text: He discovered the speed of light

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated the circumference of the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: He invented the word geography

options.label: D
options.text: He made many contributions to science, but his most notable contribution was calculating the circumference of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If you were to set up an experiment to measure the speed of light, how could you use a toothed wheel and a beam of light to determine the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: By measuring the time it takes for the light to travel between two stations

options.label: B
options.text: By counting the number of notches on the wheel and calculating the speed of the wheel

options.label: C
options.text: By noticing that the pulse of light is occluded by the wheel as it spins faster

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing the speed of the wheel to the speed of light

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of the fact that scientists like Eratosthenes and Fizeau were able to make significant discoveries using simple equipment and methods?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that science is a field that requires complex and expensive equipment

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the importance of independent corroboration in scientific research

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrates the power of human curiosity and ingenuity in scientific discovery

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that science is a closed field of study that is not accessible to everyone
